4v4 is a great size of small sided game to help players get lots of touches on the ball and in this variation with mini goals, keepers are not needed.

[/et_pb_text][et_pb_image src=”https://ts-uploads.azureedge.net/marketing/2020/03/4v4-To-Mini-Goals.png” align=”center” align_tablet=”center” align_phone=”” align_last_edited=”on|desktop” _builder_version=”4.2.2″ max_width=”85%” max_width_tablet=”” max_width_phone=”” max_width_last_edited=”on|desktop” hover_enabled=”0″][/et_pb_image][et_pb_text _builder_version=”4.2.2″ text_font=”|300|||||||” text_text_color=”#151516″ max_width=”70%” max_width_tablet=”” max_width_phone=”” max_width_last_edited=”on|desktop” module_alignment=”center” hover_enabled=”0″]

Set Up

Create a playing area with two mini goals on either end. In addition, start with two teams of four.

[/et_pb_text][et_pb_text _builder_version=”4.2.2″ text_font=”|300|||||||” text_text_color=”#151516″ max_width=”70%” max_width_tablet=”” max_width_phone=”” max_width_last_edited=”on|desktop” module_alignment=”center” hover_enabled=”0″]

How It Works

The two teams of four go head to head trying to score on their opponent’s mini goals. All the normal rules of a full sized game apply except players can do kick ins instead of throw ins and there are no corner kicks.

[/et_pb_text][et_pb_text _builder_version=”4.2.2″ text_font=”|300|||||||” text_text_color=”#151516″ max_width=”70%” max_width_tablet=”” max_width_phone=”” max_width_last_edited=”on|desktop” module_alignment=”center” hover_enabled=”0″]

Coaching Points

4v4 can offer coaches a chance to teach tactical concepts in a scaled down environment. Fundamentals such as spreading out in possession and staying compact on defense can be easier to point out in 4v4 as there are less players to organize. 

[/et_pb_text][/et_pb_column][/et_pb_row][/et_pb_section]
